pullRequest.body:
From the PFR Project.

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]
-->

nodes.body: Closing because I am not working on this, and an open PR might discourage someone else from doing the porting work from PFR to Mathlib.
I have weird build failure in files like this one, where I need to add `Finset.`, even though I don't think I changed anything that could cause a change of behaviour here.
I know what I did! I accidentally created a `MeasureTheory.Finset` namespace. Then any `open Finset` written inside the `MeasureTheory` namespace would open that new one instead of `_root_.Finset`.
It might be easier to write `( Set.univ)  ` as `[|Set.univ]` so you can use the API of `cond`

Thanks for the suggestion. I am not really sure that we should normalize the measure anymore (partly because I did not record thoroughly enough the reason for normalizing in the first place) and I need to investigate that. But if normalizing is indeed a good idea, I'll look into using `cond`.
I suppose one reason why you might want to normalize is to keep the entropy non-negative

pullRequest.title: feat: entropy of a measure

source.title: Mathlib has `-x * log x` and some things on entropy
